awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Physical Interfaces to Empower Community Connections
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance research on information technology supported communications by investigating the role of interface type and interface asymmetry on supporting social connectedness.  Social computing technology may hold the promise of increasing interpersonal connectedness, but previous work has found that certain forms of social media may have unintended social isolation effects. Thus, it is important to explicitly investigate, design for, and measure social connectedness as an outcome of social computing systems.  This project is investigating social connection in two high-impact contexts: facilitating peer support in recovery from substance use disorders and supporting intergenerational connections to reduce elder isolation and provide one-on-one mentoring for children. The prototypes have the potential to positively contribute to addressing these significant societal challenges. All prototypes developed will be open source, with all software, circuit designs, and fabrication models available for download, and this work will contribute to innovative educational integration activities.

The investigation addresses three research challenges in designing and deploying technologies for social connectedness: (1) understanding the relative tradeoffs of social connectedness systems developed as dedicated physical interfaces versus as commodity device software; (2) exploring the effect of interface asymmetry in social connectedness systems and relationships, given that previous work typically assumes that communication partners are using identical interfaces; and, (3) developing a framework for social connectedness research to support replication and meta-analyses. These research challenges are addressed through three research thrusts. The first two thrusts focus on the design and field deployment of social connectedness systems in two high impact community connection contexts, comparing interface effects based on validated social connectedness metrics. The third thrust calls for synthesizing the findings of these deployments and other relevant investigations in collaboration with leading social connectedness researchers to develop a replication framework for future work.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Social isolation is an epidemic that strongly affects the most vulnerable members of the community: children, older adults, and people with chronic health conditions. In this project, we investigated the role of technology in supporting social connection in two critical contexts: social support in recovery from substance use disorders and intergenerational community connections in a mentoring context. We built four novel prototypes that help people stay connected, discovering new approaches to embodied interaction using both commodity and bespoke hardware arrangements. The COVID pandemic increased the salience and importance of this work as critical social interactions moved to online environments. We tested our systems through month-long real-world deployments. We showed how technology could help people in recovery from substance use disorders maintain their recovery and stay engaged with social support. We demonstrated that commodity hardware could create compelling embodied communication systems in the school context, allowing older adults to build relationships with and mentor at-risk elementary school students. Based on this substantial body of empirical work, we developed implications for design and new frameworks to guide future research in social and affective computing. Finally, we demonstrated the application of this approach to novel contexts through student-led projects on social connection topics.

Broader Impacts: Our work provided important digital communication channels for people in critical contexts during the COVID pandemic: older adults were able to mentor at-risk elementary school students, and people in recovery from substance use disorders were able to maintain connections while social distancing. Beyond the impact of these research prototypes, this project led to a number of compelling educational and outreach initiatives, including a weekly student physical computing club, a new course on embodied computing, and the dissemination of insights through lay blogs and interviews. This award contributed to training six PhD students (five from underrepresented groups in Computer Science) and nine undergraduates (four from underrepresented groups) in research and innovation practices, broadening participation in computing and helping train the future high-tech workforce of this country.
